00003 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00004 
00005  #
00006  #  Declares constructors for MathObjects
00007  #
00008 
00009 =cut
00010 
00011 =head3 Constructors for the various Mathobject types
00012 
00013 =pod
00014 
00015 MathObjects are objects which behave much like you would expect
00016 their true mathematical counterparts to behave.
00017 
00018 MathObject types (classes) -- defined in Value.pl
00019 
00020     Standard
00021         Real
00022               Behave like real numbers
00023         Infinity
00024               Extended real numbers (infinities)  -- Also complex
00025               numbers???
00026             infinity
00027             - infinity
00028             infinite (either plus or minus infinity)
00029         Complex
00030               Behave like complex numbers.  The interpretations of plus
00031               and times are those standardly used for mathematical
00032               complex numbers
00033     List objects -- which means that they involve delimiters
00034       (parentheses) of some type.
00035         Point
00036         Vector
00037         Matrix
00038         List
00039     Subsets of Reals
00040         Intervals
00041         Sets (finite collections of points
00042         Union (of intervals and sets)
00043     String   -- special purpose
00044           Allows comparison with a string
00045     Formula -- roughly a function with values as defined above.
00046         Complex object whose output is one of the MathObject values
00047           listed above.
00048         A formula object contains a parse tree inside it which allows
00049           you to calculate output values from given input values.
00050         This MathObject is more complicated than the ones above.
00051 
00052 Constructing MathObjects
00053     $a = Real(3.5);
00054     $a = Real("345/45");
00055     $c = Complex(5,4);
00056     $c = Complex("5+4i");
00057 
00058 See Value.pm for MathObject methods
00059 
00060 See Parser.pm for information on turning strings into MathObjects.
00061 
00062 =cut
00063 
00064 
00065 sub String   {Value->Package("String()")->new(@_)}
00066 sub Real     {Value->Package("Real()")->new(@_)}
00067 sub Complex  {Value->Package("Complex()")->new(@_)}
00068 sub Point    {Value->Package("Point()")->new(@_)}
00069 sub Vector   {Value->Package("Vector()")->new(@_)}
00070 sub Matrix   {Value->Package("Matrix()")->new(@_)}
00071 sub List     {Value->Package("List()")->new(@_)}
00072 sub Interval {Value->Package("Interval()")->new(@_)}
00073 sub Set      {Value->Package("Set()")->new(@_)}
00074 sub Union    {Value->Package("Union()")->new(@_)}
00075 
00076 sub ColumnVector {Value->Package("Vector()")->new(@_)->with(ColumnVector=>1,open=>undef,close=>undef)}
00077 
00078 # sub Formula  {Value->Package("Formula()")->new(@_)}  # in Parser.pl
00079 
00080 =head3 Closed($point)
00081 
00082  #
00083  #  Make a point or list a closed interval.
00084  #  (Obsolete: use $x->with(open=>'[',close=>']') instead.)
00085  #
00086 
00087 =cut
00088 
00089 sub Closed {
00090   my $x = shift;
00091   if (Value::isValue($x)) {$x->{open} = '['; $x->{close} = ']'}
00092   return $x;
00093 }
00094

00099  #  Make it possible to use  1+3*i  in perl rather than  1+3*$i or 1+3*i()
00100  #  as well as 3*pi instead of 3*pi()
00101
